title: 103_hr107
content: The Act is titled the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" and it applies to various sections. The "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress as they would to private individuals or Executive agencies. The "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" extends various laws, including the Social Security Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1964, to Congress and Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends laws like the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Privacy Act of 1974, Age Discrimination Act of 1975, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 to Congress and Executive agencies. Congress and its instrumentalities are subject to the Freedom of Information Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends laws to Congress and Executive agencies, making them subject to the Freedom of Information Act and the Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends laws to Congress and Executive agencies, subjecting them to the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions. This Act applies to Senators, Representatives, Resident Commissioners, Delegates, congressional employees, elected officers, and Legislative Counsel employees. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to various individuals and entities, including elected officers, Legislative Counsel employees, Capitol Police members, and employees of Congressional instrumentalities like the Congressional Research Service and the Library of Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to entities such as the Office of the Architect of the Capitol, Botanic Gardens, Government Printing Office, Library of Congress, Congressional Budget Office, and Copyright Royalty Tribunal. District or State offices of Members are treated as affiliated branches of private employers under the Act. Members can consider political affiliation despite the Act's laws. Section 2 allows Members to consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring staff. A conforming amendment repeals Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act. Small business exemptions in laws referenced in Section 2 apply to Members based on their aggregate number of employees. The aggregate number of employees of a Member and employees attributable to the Member must not exceed the number required to qualify as a small business. The number of employees attributable to a Member is calculated based on specific subsections and divided by the number of Members in that House. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS. The House of Representatives and the Senate must each create rules within 180 days to implement this Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations. SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. If an individual is unhappy with an action taken under this Act, they can appeal in a Federal district court with the same rights as private persons under relevant laws.
